Internal Controls are the program manual’s policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the: a. Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated, and key terms are deﬁned; and b. Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations. (
) To conform to the new Internal Controls standards: a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s: mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
, Authority, is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual (Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System). c. New subsection
, Acronym, is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System). (
) Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section, did not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity of the subject matter.

Subsections 1.5.5.1 through 1.5.5.2 reﬂect the IRS requirement that IR manuals address Internal Controls (ICs). The ICs mandate is outlined in The Heightened Awareness, Sensitivity, and Understanding of Internal Controls memo dated September 14, 2016. Internal Controls are the program manual’s policies and procedures. The ICs describe the program manual’s objectives, and officials charged with management and oversight. The ICs ensure the:
Mission and program objectives are clearly delineated, and key terms are deﬁned; and Program operations are in conformance with applicable laws and regulations.
a. Former subsection

, Overview, is retitled to Program Scope and Objectives to properly reﬂect the information communicated in the subsection. The subsection clearly delineates the program manual’s: mission, objectives, and goals. The subsection provides special agents assistance in conducting criminal investigations and associated litigation activities. b. New subsection
, Authority, is added to provide the legal authorities for the program manual (Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System). c. New subsection
, Acronym, is added as a compiled list of the terms and acronyms used within the program manual (Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System).
Additional revisions, deletions, and grammatical changes were made throughout the section, which did not result in substantive changes but contributed to procedural clarity of the subject matter.
ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
This transmittal supersedes IRM 1.5.5 dated December 21, 2010.
Criminal Investigation

Authority Acronyms Application of the Manual Use of Records of Tax Enforcement Results in Other Measures and Statistics Use of Statistics for Monitoring Programs Use of Statistics in Operational Reviews
Section 1204/Regulation 801 Guidance for Criminal Investigation (CI) 1.5.5
The table lists commonly used acronyms and their deﬁnitions:

) The guidelines, restrictions and prohibitions in the use of statistics as outlined in this manual applies to all CI employees who exercise judgment in determin- ing whether or how the IRS should pursue enforcement of the tax laws against a particular individual or entity. The manual provisions are applicable to each employee based upon the speciﬁc tasks they perform and not the title of their position or the location where they are performing their tasks. (

) For most special agents and their various levels of supervisors, this circum- stance of exercising judgment applies to a majority of the tasks they perform. Those special agents who are assigned full/part time to specialty positions may be exempt from the manual provisions if they are not exercising judgment in determining whether or how the IRS should pursue enforcement of the tax laws. (

) Generally, support personnel do not execute the type of tasks in which they exercise judgment about enforcement of the tax laws. However, some support personnel (i.e., tax fraud investigative aides; investigative analysts; and interns) may make recommendations to special agents or management officials as to whether or how the IRS should pursue enforcement of the tax laws against speciﬁc individuals or entities. When making these types of recommendations, the support personnel come under the guidance of this manual.
(04-13-2020) Application of the Manual

seizures g. Dollar value of assets seized (Title
Only) h. Number of search warrants i. Number of arrests j. Number of Title
forfeitures k. Dollar value of assets forfeited (Title
Only) Note: Notwithstanding non-Title
exclusion from items (g) and (k); extreme should be utilized in referring to non-Title
seizures and forfeitures to the inference of a quantitative goal as an element of performance ment. (

) An evaluation may include a performance rating, an award recommendation, progress review, an assessment for or qualiﬁcation for promotion or a similar type of managerial determination. For more information related to progress workload reviews see IRM

A recommendation for an award outside the IRS is not subject to ROTER restrictions. Note: Any outside award recommendation or award resulting from such nomina- tions is not to be considered for performance evaluations, bonus, promotions, or reassignments. In addition, outside award recommendations are NOT to be ﬁled in an employee’s performance ﬁle (EPF). (

) Managers should not use language, such as contained in the following examples, which suggests that ROTERs were used to evaluate the The employee’s performance is to be measured against that employee’s speciﬁc critical job elements and standards. Managers may not cite a as the basis for an individual employee’s performance rating or include a ROTER in any written employee performance evaluation. In addition to the prohibition against using hard numbers on a collective basis, managers are also prohibited from using “soft language or phrases” that are suggestive of ROTERs. Examples of these type of items are: a. Successful prosecution referral of numerous individuals and entities b. Seizure of numerous luxury automobiles (Title
Only) c. Numerous search warrants were executed d. Multiple currency seizures (Title
Only) e. Subjects were charged with various Federal crimes such as... f. Substantial forfeitures of assets (Title
Only) g. Signiﬁcant amount of assets that were subject to forfeiture and seizure h. Seizure of an extremely large amount of currency (Title
Only) (

) In discussions with employees about performance, managers may discuss particular tax enforcement result achieved in a particular case or cases provided that the discussion is based upon the manager’s review of the em- ployee’s case ﬁle(s) for the speciﬁc case(s). Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

1.5 Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System
The ROTERs may not be maintained or used for the purpose of evaluating any individual employee. Examples of ROTERs include, but are not limited to:
Number of fraud referrals accepted or Fraud referral acceptance rate Number of prosecution recommendations Prosecution referral rate Number of discontinued investigations Number of Title
seizures Dollar value of assets seized (Title
Only) Number of search warrants Number of arrests Number of Title
forfeitures Dollar value of assets forfeited (Title
Only)

Note: Notwithstanding non-Title 26 exclusion from items (g) and (k); extreme care should be utilized in referring to non-Title 26 seizures and forfeitures to avoid the inference of a quantitative goal as an element of performance measure-
promotions, or reassignments. In addition, outside award recommendations are NOT to be ﬁled in an employee’s performance ﬁle (EPF). (

) Managers should not use language, such as contained in the following examples, which suggests that ROTERs were used to evaluate the The employee’s performance is to be measured against that employee’s speciﬁc critical job elements and standards. Managers may not cite a ROTER as the basis for an individual employee’s performance rating or include a ROTER in any written employee performance evaluation. In addition to the prohibition against using hard numbers on a collective basis, managers are also prohibited from using “soft language or phrases” that are suggestive of ROTERs. Examples of these type of items are:
a. Successful prosecution referral of numerous individuals and entities b. Seizure of numerous luxury automobiles (Title
Only) c. Numerous search warrants were executed d. Multiple currency seizures (Title
Only) e. Subjects were charged with various Federal crimes such as... f. Substantial forfeitures of assets (Title
Only) g. Signiﬁcant amount of assets that were subject to forfeiture and seizure h. Seizure of an extremely large amount of currency (Title

Only) In discussions with employees about performance, managers may discuss the particular tax enforcement result achieved in a particular case or cases provided that the discussion is based upon the manager’s review of the em- ployee’s case ﬁle(s) for the speciﬁc case(s).
Guidance for Criminal

) However, the discussion of the particular tax enforcement result obtained should only be to the extent that it is necessary to fairly and fully determine employee’s exercise of appropriate judgment in arriving at that speciﬁc tax forcement result. The emphasis of the manager’s discussion should be directed towards the measurement of the employee’s performance against employee’s critical job elements and standards and how the execution of critical job elements achieved the speciﬁc tax enforcement result. It is that this type of discussion will occur most frequently in the critical job elements for “court related activities” and “other enforcement activities”. (

) Annual performance plans for managers will be prepared and agreed upon without ROTERs being cited in the written plan. Evaluations for all levels of management will be based upon the individual manager’s actions taken in cordance with that manager’s annual agreed upon performance plan. (

) Performance measures (i.e., Customer Satisfaction; Employee Satisfac- tion; Business Results of Quality, Quantity and Outreach) may only be used as an analytical input tool in preparing managerial evaluations. Managers may use performance measures in determining whether the actions taken by the subordinate manager being evaluated achieved desired performance result as speciﬁed in the annual performance (

) Performance measures may not be used as a stand-alone measure to determine the individual manager’s evaluation rating when comparing achievements to their annual performance plan. As with all non-supervisory employee evaluations, managerial evaluations must not cite any ROTERs. (

) Managers are free to discuss tax enforcement results with the subordi- nate manager being evaluated, but the manager’s evaluation is to emphasize the subordinate manager’s performance against his/her annual agreed upon performance plan. (

) Self- assessment information prepared by employees or managers must not contain ROTERs. For employees, this includes knowledge, skills, and (KSA) statements prepared and submitted as part of the promotion ranking package. It is important that supervisors review all KSA statements before are submitted to the host personnel site. The manager should review the statements for ROTERs, as well as the accuracy of the statements made by the employee. If an employee or manager submits self-assessment containing a ROTER, the management official receiving the information must return the information to the employee or manager and the management official must retain any copies of the information. (

) The manager will ask the employee to submit a new self-assessment the ROTER. The manager may not consider or use the submitted ROTER in an evaluation of the employee. The manager is also required to inform the employee that the information received contained a ROTER and the will identify the ROTER for the employee. (
) The manager will counsel the employee so that the employee understands proper use of statistics within the IRS and the IRS’ policy on the use of tics.
1204/Regulation 801 Guidance for Criminal (CI) 1.5.5
The manager will counsel the employee so that the employee understands the proper use of statistics within the IRS and the IRS’ policy on the use of statis-
Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement (

) Balance Measures and diagnostic tools were developed to assist all to better utilize their resources. They provide insight into organizational processes and performance. Managers are expected to use these measures and tools to help them achieve an appropriate mix of Customer Satisfaction, Employee Satisfaction, and Business results. (

) Statistics that do not relate directly to cases are not considered to be Included in these type of statistics are: a. Items that are related to case closures b. Time applied per case c. Cycle time d. Inventory information e. Overage items f. Administrative actions and resources expended (

) Examples of these items may include, but are not limited to: • Elapsed time on discontinued investigations • Percentage of direct investigative time (DIT) for legal source tax Illegal Source Financial Crimes; Narcotics Related Financial Crimes; Refund Crimes; Electronic Crimes and all major subprograms • Percentage of overage cases at various level • Elapsed time/applied time on prosecution recommendations • CIMIS input rate (

) Although the items referred to above are not considered ROTERs, managers must exercise caution in using this information. Managers must not use the information in a way that suggests to employees or subordinate managers in- appropriate behavior regarding the exercise of judgment in enforcing the tax laws against individuals or entities. (

) Criminal Investigation also measures and tracks other data that does relate directly to individual cases. This data may represent the result of enforcement determinations controlled in whole or in part by another government entity may include information which qualiﬁes as a ROTER. If so, the data should treated as a ROTER by CI. (
) Managers are prohibited from using the data in a manner that may suggest a goal or a quota. Instead, the items referenced in items numbers two (
) and three (
) above, should be used as diagnostic tools by managers to the root causes of suspected problem areas. (
) This process is further described in subsection
regarding the use of statistics in preparing for and conducting operational reviews. (

) The regulation also restricts the use of quantity measures. Quantity Measures are considered outcome neutral such as number of cases closed, work items completed etc. The regulation prohibits the evaluation of or the suggestion of production goal or quota to any non-supervisory employee who is responsible for exercising judgment with respect to tax enforcement results (See Regula- tion

)). Within organizational units quantity measures must be used in conjunction with an evaluation or goals based upon all three elements (Customer Satisfaction; Employee Satisfaction and Business Results) of the Balanced Measurement System. See IRM
(subsection
, Permitted Use of ROTERs) for more information regarding Quantity Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.
I
1.5 Managing Statistics in a Balanced Measurement System
Guidance for Criminal (CI)
) ROTERs may be used at the national, regional, or ﬁeld office level to direct and control program accomplishments and direction. (

) Management officials participating in the activities of monitoring, directing controlling program accomplishments and direction must use caution that use of ROTERS in authorized circumstances does not suggest or impose goals or quotas for subordinate employees or organization units. Further, agement officials may not use ROTERS to compare or rank organizational units or to evaluate the managers of those organizational units. (

) Some examples of the type of authorized activities in which ROTERS may used include: a. Long range planning b. Financial planning c. Allocation of resources d. Work planning and control e. Formulation of case selection criteria, f. Effective functional management and g. Staffing utilization systems and plans. (
) Organizational units may share balanced measurers and other non-ROTER data at the same level. (

) Goals for the Balanced Measures System will be set at the National level to satisfy government reporting requirements. Goals will be set no lower than ﬁeld office level. They will not be used to directly determine the evaluation an organizational unit or an individual employee. (

) ROTERs may be used to prepare for operational reviews at the national, ﬁeld office, branch and group levels. ROTERS should only be used as tors to identify variances, whether above or below the norm. The ROTERS be used to identify areas where further investigation is needed. Speciﬁc will eventually be selected for further review. The purpose of the additional analysis and review will be to determine the quality of the processes in the area of concern within the organizational unit. (

) The review and analysis may be conducted by local management officials through a ﬁeld visitation by outside management personnel. The speciﬁc review should go beyond the raw statistics and should focus on the process best determine what might be causing a variance. (

) The following information cannot be disclosed pursuant to the certiﬁcation process: a. Grand jury investigation information b. Information relating to sensitive items such as ongoing criminal tions c. Informant agreements and related documents d. Information concerning undercover operations (

) The employee performance ﬁle and performance appraisal documents, are the required documents to be reviewed in the certiﬁcation process, will the primary documents subject to review in CI by the independent review
Section 1204/Regulation 801 Guidance for Criminal Investigation (CI) 1.5.5
ROTERs may be used at the national, regional, or ﬁeld office level to monitor, direct and control program accomplishments and direction.

teams. The independent review team will review one or more additional review items as designated by the appropriate supervisor. Additional review items are outlined in IRM 1.5.3 (see subsection 1.5.3.8.4(4), and must not be in conﬂict with subsection 1.5.5.7.(1).
Operational and workload review documents containing any information ﬁed in paragraph (1) above must be excluded from the independent review.
